channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Guilty of Culpable Homicide
item.description: Oscar Pistorius was found guilty of a charge equivalent to manslaughter in the shooting of Reeva Steenkamp, but he was granted bail and will remain free until sentencing procedures on Oct. 13.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Rift Emerges in Sweden Over Immigration
item.description: National elections will be held on Sunday, and the center-right government has lost some supporters to an anti-immigrant alternative.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CROUCH
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt of Sweden has decided to gamble re-election on embracing the country’s tradition of openness.

item.title: Ukraine President Says Truce Is Growing Stronger
item.description: President Petro O. Poroshenko, who has been trying to generate a sense of momentum for a lasting cease-fire, also ruled out trying to take back Crimea by force.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Rob Ford, Toronto Mayor, Withdraws Re-election Bid
item.description: Minutes after the announcement, a representative for Doug Ford, the mayor’s brother who is a City Council member, formally registered him as a mayoral candidate.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Ebola Outpaces Global Response, W.H.O. Says
item.description: A doubling of the number of new cases in Liberia this week from the week before is of particular concern, the U.N. health agency said.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Elite Israeli Officers Decry Treatment of Palestinians
item.description: In a letter sent to commanders and the prime minister, 43 veteran officers of a vaunted intelligence unit said they would refuse required reserve duty.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: As Aspiring Jihadists Heed Call of ISIS, Home Nations Try to Stymie Them
item.description: Lawmakers around the world are debating laws intended to stop citizens from going abroad to fight, and to punish them if they do.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: U.S. and European Sanctions Take Aim at Putin’s Economic Efforts
item.description: The measures take aim at financial, defense and industrial companies at the vanguard of a push by the Russian leader to replace wild free-market capitalism with state-led development.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Foreign Journalists in China See Decline in Reporting Conditions
item.description: Conditions for foreign journalists working in China have gone from bad to worse over the past year, according to a report issued on Friday by the Foreign Correspondents’ Club of China.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Journalists waiting outside the Great Hall of the People during the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference in Beijing in March.

item.title: 10 Militants Held in Shooting of Malala Yousafzai, Girls’ Education Advocate, Pakistan Says
item.description: The militants have been accused of the 2012 attack on the schoolgirl, who was shot in head on a school bus in Swat Valley.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: China Court Sentences 3 to Death Over Attack at Railroad Station
item.description: The defendants were found guilty of leading a terrorist group that killed 31 people at the railroad station in Kunming in March.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Ian Paisley, Ulster Hard-Liner Who Made Peace, Dies at 88
item.description: The Protestant leader who vowed never to compromise with Irish Catholic nationalists accepted in his twilight a power-sharing agreement after decades of sectarian violence.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

item.title: At War Blog: Writing as a Soldier and a Civilian
item.description: A soldier takes time out of uniform to pursue an M.F.A. in writing, and discovers that what sets him apart, as a veteran at the keyboard, is not as important as the common ground he shares with other writers.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW KOMATSU

item.title: Mexican Rights Groups File Suit for ‘Systematic and Widespread’ Abuse by Army and Police
item.description: The complaint asks the International Criminal Court to investigate charges of torture, capture and disappearances of civilians in Baja California between 2006 and 2012.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MARLISE SIMONS

item.title: Germany Bans Support for ISIS
item.description: The crackdown on displays of the ISIS flag and activities that encourage recruitment was announced amid a growing Western-led drive to galvanize countries around the world.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Thieves Follow the Money to Corrupt Officials’ Homes
item.description: Corrupt officials make ideal targets: They are known to keep large supplies of cash in their residences and are reluctant to report thefts for fear of a graft investigation.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Corrupt officials are thought to keep much of their ill-gotten gains in cash to avoid bank accounts that might attract the attention of investigators.

item.title: Cuba to Send Expanded Medical Team to Fight Ebola
item.description: The commitment of personnel to the health crisis is the biggest from any country, but it remains insufficient, the top United Nations health official warned.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Letter From Europe: NATO’s Hopes for Russia Have Turned to Dismay
item.description: In a declaration at a summit 24 years ago, NATO expressed elation at the thought of a democratic future for Eastern Europe, but those hopes seem so much dust today.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Australia Raises Terrorism Alert Level to High
item.description: Prime Minister Tony Abbott said Friday that there was “a body of evidence that points to the increased likelihood of a terrorist attack in Australia.”
item.dc:creator: By MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Chinese Dissident’s Trial Is Cut Short After Lawyers Refuse to Attend
item.description: A lawyer for the dissident, best known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, said that “whatever a lawyer said in the courtroom would have no effect.”
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Expands Investment in Tanzania
item.description: China is providing $412.5 million to build a logistics hub in the Tanzanian port of Dar es Salaam.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China with President Jakaya Kikwete of Tanzania in Dar es Salaam last year. During his Africa tour, Mr. Xi tried to address concerns that China was only interested in Africa’s natural resources.

item.title: Oscar Pistorius Returns to Court as Judge Ponders Charges
item.description: Judge Thokozile Matilda Masipa is ruling on lesser charges after finding he did not commit premeditated murder.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius arriving at the courthouse in Pretoria, South Africa, on Friday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In China, a Search for Oscar Contenders
item.description: “Gone with the Bullets,” “Coming Home” and “Wolf Totem” are attracting notice as possible Academy Award entrants. A film from mainland China has yet to win an Oscar, and officials are eager for the cultural validation that the award would bring.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Jiang Wen at a news conference in Beijing for his film "Gone with the Bullets."

item.title: Retired Gen. John R. Allen in Line to Lead Effort vs. ISIS
item.description: Mr. Allen, who was the top American commander in Afghanistan, will coordinate the international coalition to fight the militant Islamist group, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Japanese Newspaper Retracts Fukushima Disaster Report and Fires Editor
item.description: The move comes a month after The Asahi Shimbun retracted articles on another hot-button issue about Japan’s wartime legacy: women forced to serve in brothels.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The Asahi Shimbun was distributed on a Tokyo street last year.
